fu.geo

Class Spherical

  • java.lang.Object
    • fu.geo.Spherical

  • public class Spherical
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides spherical geometry computations, e.g. great circles sizes or area sizes of geometries on the Earth's surface.

    • Method Detail

      • precomputeDistanceCircle

        public static double[] precomputeDistanceCircle(double lat,
                                                double lon,
                                                double meters)
        Precomputes values to check later, if a given position is inside a circle. Using precomputeDistanceCircle() once and isInsideDistanceCircle() later several times is much faster than asking greatCircleMeters()>meters.
        Parameters:
        lat - circle center latitude
        lon - circle centerlongitude
        meters - circle radius
        Returns:
        precomputed circle defintion

      • isInsideDistanceCircle

        public static boolean isInsideDistanceCircle(double[] precomputeDistanceCircle,
                                             double lat,
                                             double lon)
        Asks if a given position is inside a precomputed circle. Precomputation has do be done by precomputeDistanceCircle.
        Parameters:
        lat - position latitude
        lon - position longitude
        precomputeDistanceCircle - precomputed circle definition with precomputeDistanceCircle
        Returns:
        true if inside

      • isInsideDistanceCircle

        public static boolean isInsideDistanceCircle(double[] precomputeDistanceCircle,
                                             double[] prCompLanLon)
        Asks if a given position is inside a precomputed circle. Precomputation has do be done by precomputeDistanceCircle and precomputeLatLon.
        Parameters:
        prCompLanLon - precomputed lat lon position latitude with precomputeLatLon
        precomputeDistanceCircle - precomputed circle definition with precomputeDistanceCircle
        Returns:
        true if inside

      • latitudeNorthOf

        public static double latitudeNorthOf(double lat,
                                     double meters)
        Moves a given coordinate to north by a specific distance in meters. Only the latitude value of the new coordinate is returned, the longitude coordinate remains the same. Negative meters means: moving to south. The longitude coordinate of the start position is not passed as it does not affect the result.
        Parameters:
        lat - position latitude
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        latitude of the translated position

      • latitudeNorthOf

        public static double latitudeNorthOf(double lat,
                                     double lon,
                                     double meters)
        Moves a given coordinate to north by a specific distance in meters. Only the latitude value of the new coordinate is returned, the longitude coordinate remains the same. Negative meters means: moving to south. The longitude coordinate of the start position is only passed only for symmetry reasons the the methon longitudeEastOf, but does not affect the result.
        Parameters:
        lat - position latitude
        lon - position longitude
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        latitude of the translated position

      • latitudeDegrees

        public static double latitudeDegrees(double meters)
        Computes degrees for a distance in meters in south/north direction.
        Parameters:
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        degrees that represent the amount of meters

      • longitudeEastOf

        public static double longitudeEastOf(double lat,
                                     double lon,
                                     double meters)
        Moves a given coordinate to east by a specific distance in meters. Only the longitude value of the new coordinate is returned, the latitude coordinate remains the same. Negative meters means: moving to west.
        Parameters:
        lat - position latitude
        lon - position longitude
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        longitude of the translated position

      • metersPerDegAtLatitude

        public static double metersPerDegAtLatitude(double lat)
        How many meters has a degree of longitude (i.e. parellel to the equator) at a certain latitude? In other words: at a certain latidute you move for every longitude degree longitude*metersPerDegAtLatitude(latitude) meters.
        Parameters:
        lat - latitude part of any position
        Returns:
        size in meters of a degree longitude

      • longitudeDegrees

        public static double longitudeDegrees(double lat,
                                      double meters)
        Computes degrees for a distance in meters in west/east direction. As the relation of degrees and meters change for different latitude, the latitude has to be passed.
        Parameters:
        lat - latitude part of any position
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        degrees that represent the amount of meters

      • extendMBR

                                 double meters)
        Increase a bounding rect by a certain amount of meters in each direction.
        Parameters:
        mbr - array with minLat, maxLat, minLon, maxLon, also the result (i.e. the extended MBR)
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        extended MBR as array with minLat, maxLat, minLon, maxLon

      • moveMeters

        public static double[] moveMeters(double lat1,
                                  double lon1,
                                  double lat2,
                                  double lon2,
                                  double meters)
        Moves along a certain amount of meters from the first position to the second. 0 meters returns the first position. Positive meters move meters along to the second position. Negative meters recedes from the second position. Important: this function linearly interpolates between both position and does not use great circle formulas. Thus this function only is useful for smaller amount of meters and close first and second positions. E.g. for positions with distance of 1 degree we get 3 meters error per 1000 meters.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - latitude of first position
        lon1 - longitude of first position
        lat2 - latitude of second position
        lon2 - longitude of second position
        meters - amount of meters
        Returns:
        array of two [0]: latitude, [1]: longitude

      • greatCircleAngleCached

        public static double greatCircleAngleCached(double lat1,
                                            double lon1,
                                            double lat2,
                                            double lon2)
        Returns the great circle's length in rad angle (0...2PI). This is a "cached" version. This means, if two subsequent calls have one or two equal coordinates, the cached values of sin and cos are used. This is useful, e.g. if for route planning the distance to a certain target is computed million times.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - latitude of first position
        lon1 - longitude of first position
        lat2 - latitude of second position
        lon2 - longitude of second position
        Returns:
        angle in rad

      • greatCircleAngle

        public static double greatCircleAngle(double lat1,

                                      double lat2,
                                      double lon2)

        Parameters:

        lon1 - longitude of first position
        lat2 - latitude of second position
        lon2 - longitude of second position
        Returns:
        angle in rad

      • precomputeLatLon

        public static double[] precomputeLatLon(double lat,
                                        double lon)
        Precompute relevant data to compute greatCircleAnglePrecomputed later.
        Parameters:
        lat - position latitude
        lon - position longitude
        Returns:
        array of 4 [0]: lat in rad, [1]: lon in rad [2]: sin(lat) [3]: cos(lat)

      • greatCircleMetersPrecomputed

        public static double greatCircleMetersPrecomputed(double[] prComp1,
                                                  double[] prComp2)
        Returns the great circle's length in meters. All parameters are pre-computed, i.e. in rad and sin/cos are already there, precomputed by precomputeLatLon().
        Parameters:
        prComp1 - first position (precomputed)
        prComp2 - second position (precomputed)
        Returns:
        distance in meters

      • greatCircleMetersCached

        public static double greatCircleMetersCached(double lat1,
                                             double lon1,
                                             double lat2,
                                             double lon2)
        Returns the great circle's length in meters. This is a "cached" version. This means, if two subsequent calls have one or two equal coordinates, the cached values of sin and cos are used. This is useful, e.g. if for route planning the distance to a certain target is computed million times.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - latitude of first position
        lon1 - longitude of first position
        lat2 - latitude of second position
        lon2 - longitude of second position
        Returns:
        distance in meters

      • surfaceAngle

        public static double surfaceAngle(double lat,
                                  double lon,
                                  double latA,
                                  double lonA,
                                  double latB,
                                  double lonB)
        Compute the angle on the Earth's surface between the two great circles (lat,lon) to (latA,lonA) and (lat,lon) to (latB,lonB), i.e. the angle is measured at position (lat,lon).
        Parameters:
        lat - position from with A->B is viewed (latitude)
        lon - position from with A->B is viewed (longitude)
        latA - first position latitude
        lonA - first position longitude
        latB - second position latitude
        lonB - second position longitude
        Returns:
        angle in degrees (absolute value)

      • signedSurfaceAngle

        public static double signedSurfaceAngle(double lat,
                                        double lon,
                                        double latA,
                                        double lonA,
                                        double latB,
                                        double lonB)
        Compute a signed surface angle. Greater than 0 means: from the given point looking from point A to point B goes counter clockwise.
        Parameters:
        lat - position from with A->B is viewed (latitude)
        lon - position from with A->B is viewed (longitude)
        latA - first position latitude
        lonA - first position longitude
        latB - second position latitude
        lonB - second position longitude
        Returns:
        angle in degree

      • northAngle

        public static double northAngle(double latA,
                                double lonA,
                                double latB,
                                double lonB)
        Computes the angle between A and B and the north direction. E.g.
        • 0: A -> B goes north
        • 180: A -> B goes south
        • 90: A -> B goes east (for positive longitude-values east of Greenwhich)
        • -90: A -> B goes west (for positive longitude-values east of Greenwhich)
        Parameters:
        latA - first position latitude
        lonA - first position longitude
        latB - second position latitude
        lonB - second position longitude
        Returns:
        angle in degree

      • sphericTriangleArea

        public static double sphericTriangleArea(double lat1,
                                         double lon1,
                                         double lat2,
                                         double lon2,
                                         double lat3,
                                         double lon3)
        Returns the spherical area size of a triangle in square meters.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - of latitude of triangle vertex 1
        lon1 - of longitude of triangle vertex 1
        lat2 - of latitude of triangle vertex 2
        lon2 - of longitude of triangle vertex 2
        lat3 - of latitude of triangle vertex 3
        lon3 - of longitude of triangle vertex 3
        Returns:
        area size in m2

      • sphericQuadrangleArea

        public static double sphericQuadrangleArea(double lat1,
                                           double lon1,
                                           double lat2,
                                           double lon2,
                                           double lat3,
                                           double lon3,
                                           double lat4,
                                           double lon4)
        Returns the spherical area size of a quadrangle in square meters. Note: the quadrangle does not have to fulfull any constraints (e.g. does not have to be rectangular).
        Parameters:
        lat1 - of latitude of quadrangle vertex 1
        lon1 - of longitude of quadrangle vertex 1
        lat2 - of latitude of quadrangle vertex 2
        lon2 - of longitude of quadrangle vertex 2
        lat3 - of latitude of quadrangle vertex 3
        lon3 - of longitude of quadrangle vertex 3
        lat4 - of latitude of quadrangle vertex 4
        lon4 - of longitude of quadrangle vertex 4
        Returns:
        area size in m2

      • sphericPolygonArea

        public static double sphericPolygonArea(double[] lat,
                                        double[] lon)
        Returns the area size of a polygon on the Earth's surface in square meters. Note: the first and last polygone point do not have to be identical, i.e. the polygon ist closed by the algorithm. The algorithm works as follows:
        • first compute a center of gravity for the polygon
        • for each poly edge: build a triangle with that edge and the center
        • from the edge orientation decide, whether to add or subtract the triangle area
        Parameters:
        lat - array of latitudes of polygon vertices
        lon - array of longitudes of polygon vertices
        Returns:
        area size in m2

      • latLongToCartesian

        public static double[] latLongToCartesian(double lat,
                                          double lon)
        Converts lat/long coordinate to x/y/z Cartesian. It is assumed that the position is on the altitude=0.
        Parameters:
        lat - latitude
        lon - longitude
        Returns:
        array of 3 [0]=x, [1]=y, [2]=z

      • cartesianToLatLong

        public static double[] cartesianToLatLong(double x,
                                          double y,
                                          double z)
        Converts x/y/z Cartesian to lat/lon (altitude=0). Caution: this method required the cartesian coordinate to reside on the earth surface, i.e. the euclidean distance (0,0,0) to (x, y, z) must be MEAN_EARTH_RADIUS.
        Parameters:
        x - cartesian x
        y - cartesian y
        z - cartesian z
        Returns:
        array of 2 [0]=lat, [1]=long

      • metersToGreatCircle

        public static double[] metersToGreatCircle(double lat,
                                           double lon,
                                           double lat1,
                                           double lon1,
                                           double lat2,
                                           double lon2,
                                           boolean onlyBetween)
        Computes the distance between a position (lat,lon) and a great circle line defined by two further positions (lat1/lon1...lat2/lon2). onlyBetween=true means: the nearest point has to be between (lat1/lon1...lat2/lon2), onlyBetween=false means, it can be anywhere on the great circle. The result is an array of 5:
        • [0] nearest point lat
        • [1] nearest point long
        • [2] meters between given und nearest point
        • [3] portion of nearest point between start and end (i.e. 0.0: nearest point on (lat1,lon1), 1.0 nearest point on (lat2,lon2)). For onlyBetween=true it always is between 0.0 and 1.0.
        • [4] meters between (lat1/lon1...lat2/lon2)
        Parameters:
        lat - point from which the distance is measured (latitude)
        lon - point from which the distance is measured (longitude)
        lat1 - great circle point 1 (latitude)
        lon1 - great circle point 1 (longitude)
        lat2 - great circle point 2 (latitude)
        lon2 - great circle point 2 (longitude)
        onlyBetween - if true, the distance is measured to a position between (lat1/lon1...lat2/lon2)
        Returns:
        array of 5, description see above

      • vectorProduct

        public static double[] vectorProduct(double[] p1,
                                     double[] p2)
        Computes the cross product (vector product) of the cartesian 3D vectors.
        Parameters:
        p1 - cartesian vector1
        p2 - cartesian vector2
        Returns:
        cartesian result vector

      • vectorProductRobust

        public static double[] vectorProductRobust(double lat1,
                                           double lon1,
                                           double lat2,
                                           double lon2)
        Computes the cross product (vector product) of the cartesian vectors represented by lat,lon. The result of 
         vectorProductRobust(lat1,lon1,lat2,lon2);
        is apart from scale, the same as 
         vectorProduct(latLongToCartesian(lat1,lon1),latLongToCartesian(lat2,lon2));
        However, the respective computation is more robust against rounding errors.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - latitude of first position
        lon1 - longitude of first position
        lat2 - latitude of second position
        lon2 - longitude of second position
        Returns:
        cartesian result vector

      • normalizeTo

        public static void normalizeTo(double[] p,
                               double len)
        Normalizes a cartesian 3D vector to the given length.
        Parameters:
        p - cartesian vector (also stores the result)
        len - length of result vector

      • metersToLineString

        public static double[] metersToLineString(double lat,
                                          double lon,
                                          double[] lineStringLats,
                                          double[] lineStringLongs)
        Computes the nearest point to a line string. The result is an array of 7:
        • [0] nearest point lat
        • [1] nearest point long
        • [2] meters between given und nearest point
        • [3] portion of nearest point between start and end (i.e. 0.0: nearest point on line string start, 1.0 nearest point on line string end)
        • [4] segment number (as double) on which the nearest point resides (0...number_of_points-2)
        • [5] portion of nearest point inside the segment (i.e. 0.0: first segment point, 1.0: second segment point)
        • [6] sum meters of the line string
        Parameters:
        lat - point to check with the line string (latitude)
        lon - point to check with the line string (latitude)
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        Returns:
        array of 7, see above

      • metersToLineString

        public static double[] metersToLineString(double lat,
                                          double lon,
                                          double[] lineStringLats,
                                          double[] lineStringLongs,
                                          int fromPosNr,
                                          int toPosNr)
        Same as above, but the range of positions is defined. Note that fromPosNr can be greater than toPosNr. In this case, the segments are checked in decreasing order. This also affects the portion between start and end. 0.0 always means: fromPosNr, even it is greater than toPosNr.
        Parameters:
        lat - point to check with the line string (latitude)
        lon - point to check with the line string (latitude)
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        fromPosNr - index of first considered vertex
        toPosNr - index of last considered vertex
        Returns:
        array of 7, see above

      • precomputeMetersToLineString

        public static double[][] precomputeMetersToLineString(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                      double[] lineStringLongs)
        Perform precomputation for metersToLineString. This is useful, if metersToLineString is called multiple times with the same line string.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        Returns:
        precomputed information about the line string

      • precomputeMetersToLineString

        public static double[][] precomputeMetersToLineString(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                      double[] lineStringLongs,
                                                      int fromPosNr,
                                                      int toPosNr)
        Perform precomputation for metersToLineString. This is useful, if metersToLineString is called multiple times with the same line string. Same as above, but the range of positions is defined.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        fromPosNr - index of first considered vertex
        toPosNr - index of last considered vertex
        Returns:
        precomputed information about the line string

      • metersToLineStringPrecomputed

        public static double[] metersToLineStringPrecomputed(double lat,
                                                     double lon,
                                                     double[][] preComps)
        Computes the nearest point to a line string. The line string is precomputed. The result is an array of 7:
        • [0] nearest point lat
        • [1] nearest point long
        • [2] meters between given und nearest point
        • [3] portion of nearest point between start and end (i.e. 0.0: nearest point on line string start, 1.0 nearest point on line string end)
        • [4] segment number (as double) on which the nearest point resides (0...number_of_points-2)
        • [5] portion of nearest point inside the segment (i.e. 0.0: first segment point, 1.0: second segment point)
        • [6] sum meters of the line string
        Parameters:
        lat - point to check with the line string (latitude)
        lon - point to check with the line string (latitude)
        preComps - precomputed line string
        Returns:
        array of 7, see above

      • lineStringLength

        public static double lineStringLength(double[] lineStringLats,
                                      double[] lineStringLongs)
        Computes the length in meters of a linestring.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        Returns:
        length in meters

      • cutOutLineStringByMeters

        public static double[][] cutOutLineStringByMeters(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                  double[] lineStringLongs,
                                                  double fromMeters,
                                                  double toMeters)
        Cuts out a sub linestring of a line string. The cut region is defined by driving meters (from...to).
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        fromMeters - first meter of the result line string
        toMeters - last meter of the result line string
        Returns:
        array of 2 with [0]: lineStringLats, [1]: lineStringLongs of the sub linestring.

      • projectMetersToLineString

        public static double[] projectMetersToLineString(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                 double[] lineStringLongs,
                                                 double meters,
                                                 boolean exceed)
        Walk a certain amount of meters along the linestring. Return the position you reached.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        meters - amount of meters to walk
        exceed - if true: first or last point are used, if meters exceed (i.e. <0 or >length)
        Returns:
        array[3]: [0]: latitude, [1]: longitude, [2]: segment number (as double) of the line string that contains the nearest point (0...). Is null, if meters are negative or exceed the line string length and exceed==false.

      • projectPortionToLineString

        public static double[] projectPortionToLineString(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                  double[] lineStringLongs,
                                                  double portion,
                                                  boolean exceed)
        Walk a certain amount of the line along the linestring. Return the position you reached. The amout to walk is given as portion: 0.0 means first point, 1.0 means last point, inbetween: use the portion of the total length in meters to walk.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string latitudes
        lineStringLongs - line string longitudes
        portion - amount to walk
        exceed - if true: first or last point are used, if <0 or >1
        Returns:
        array[3]: [0]: latitude, [1]: longitude, [2]: segment number (as double) of the line string that contains the nearest point (0...). Is null, if meters are negative or exceed the line string length and exceed==false.

      • intersectLineWithCircle

        public static double[] intersectLineWithCircle(double lat1,
                                               double lon1,
                                               double lat2,
                                               double lon2,
                                               double latC,
                                               double lonC,
                                               double meters,
                                               boolean cutToLine)
        Intersects line 1->2 with circle (C,meters). The result is an interval on the line 1->2 that completely resides in the circle. The interval is expressed in meters. An example: the result [1000,2000] means: driving from position 1 to position 2 after 1000 meters we come in range of the circle (i.e. we exacly have the distance in meters to C), between 1000 and 2000 meters we are closer than meters to C and after 200 meters we again have the exact distance to C. Note that the result can be empty if the circle is farer than meters away from the line. Important: this uses euclidean approach and is not fully based on great circle formulas. Thus this function only is useful for smaller amount of meters and close first and second positions.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - line's first position (latitude)
        lon1 - line's first position (longitude)
        lat2 - line's second position (latitude)
        lon2 - line's second position (longitude)
        latC - circle's first position (latitude)
        lonC - circle's first position (longitude)
        meters - circle's radius
        cutToLine - if true the interval is cut to the line start and end (i.e. cannot be smaller than 0 meters and not larger than the line length). Then also the nearest point resides on the line. If false, the line is considers as unlimited line that goes through positions 1 and 2.
        Returns:
        array of of 5 (no interval found) or 7 (interval found)
        • [0]: length in meters between position 1 and 2
        • [1]: nearest point to C in meters from position 1 (also if farer than meters, cut to 1->2 if cutToLine==true)
        • [2]: distance in meters from C to point found in [1]
        • [3]: nearest point latitude
        • [4]: nearest point longititude
        • [5]: from interval meters (if interval found)
        • [6]: to interval meters (if interval found)

      • segmentMeters

        public static double[] segmentMeters(double[] lineStringLats,
                                     double[] lineStringLongs)
        Compute a lengths list for the given positions.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string positions (latitude)
        lineStringLongs - line string positions (longitude)
        Returns:
        list of distances between to positions ([0]: 0-1, [1]: 1-2..., thus this array contains one element less than positions).

      • precomputeIntersectLineStringWithCircle

        public static double[][] precomputeIntersectLineStringWithCircle(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                                 double[] lineStringLongs)
        Performs precomputations for intersectLineStringWithCircle. If intersectLineStringWithCircle is called multiple times for the same line string, this significantly improves execution time.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string positions (latitude)
        lineStringLongs - line string positions (longitude)
        Returns:
        precomputed line string definitions

      • intersectLineStringWithCircle

        public static java.util.ArrayList<double[]> intersectLineStringWithCircle(double[] lineStringLats,
                                                                          double[] lineStringLongs,
                                                                          double latC,
                                                                          double lonC,
                                                                          double meters)
        Intersects line string with circle (C, meters). The result is a list of intervals on the line that completely resides in the circle. Any interval is expressed in meters (from, to) from the beginning of the line string. An example: the result [1000,2000] means: driving from line string start to end after 1000 meters we come in range of the circle (i.e. we exacly have the distance in meters to C), between 1000 and 2000 meters we are closer than meters to C and after 200 meters we again have the exact distance to C. Note that there may be no interval if the circle is farer than meters away from the line. Important: this uses euclidean approach and is not fully based on great circle formulas. Thus this function only is useful for smaller amount of meters and close line string positions.
        Parameters:
        lineStringLats - line string positions (latitude)
        lineStringLongs - line string positions (longitude)
        latC - the circle center (latitude)
        lonC - the circle center (longitude)
        meters - the circle radius (meters)
        Returns:
        a list with first a single set of general data, followed by the detected meter intervals. In more detail: get(0)[] is an array of 6 with
        • [0]: total length (route meters) of the line string
        • [1]: route meters of the nearest point to C
        • [2]: nearest distance to C
        • [3]: nearest point latitude
        • [4]: nearest point longititude
        • [5]: index number in the list of the interval of the nearest point (1, 2, 3), or -1, if the nearest point is farer than meters
        and get(1)[], get(2)[]... are arrays of 4 with
        • [0]: from interval route meters
        • [1]: to interval route meters
        • [2]: nearest position route meters
        • [3]: distance C to nearest position in meters

      • intersectLineStringWithCirclePrecomputed

        public static java.util.ArrayList<double[]> intersectLineStringWithCirclePrecomputed(double[][] preComps,
                                                                                     double latC,
                                                                                     double lonC,
                                                                                     double meters)
        Intersects line string with circle (C, meters). The caller passes the precomputed information. This is useful, if this method is called multiple times for the same line string. The result is a list of intervals on the line that completely resides in the circle. Any interval is expressed in meters (from, to) from the beginning of the line string. An example: the result [1000,2000] means: driving from line string start to end after 1000 meters we come in range of the circle (i.e. we exacly have the distance in meters to C), between 1000 and 2000 meters we are closer than meters to C and after 200 meters we again have the exact distance to C. Note that there may be no interval if the circle is farer than meters away from the line. Important: this uses euclidean approach and is not fully based on great circle formulas. Thus this function only is useful for smaller amount of meters and close line string positions.
        Parameters:
        preComps - the line string in precomputed format as returned by precomputeIntersectLineStringWithCircle
        latC - the circle center (latitude)
        lonC - the circle center (longitude)
        meters - the circle radius (meters)
        Returns:
        a list with first a single set of general data, followed by the detected meter intervals. In more detail: get(0)[] is an array of 6 with
        • [0]: total length (route meters) of the line string
        • [1]: route meters of the nearest point to C
        • [2]: nearest distance to C
        • [3]: nearest point latitude
        • [4]: nearest point longititude
        • [5]: index number in the list of the interval of the nearest point (1, 2, 3), or -1, if the nearest point is farer than meters
        and get(1)[], get(2)[]... are arrays of 4 with
        • [0]: from interval route meters
        • [1]: to interval route meters
        • [2]: nearest position route meters
        • [3]: distance C to nearest position in meters

      • circleCenterFromThreePoints

        public static double[] circleCenterFromThreePoints(double lat1,
                                                   double lon1,
                                                   double lat2,
                                                   double lon2,
                                                   double lat3,
                                                   double lon3)
        Computes the circle on the Earth's surfaces that contains three points. The approach is based on the paper "Spherical Geometry in Mirifiques aventures de maitre Antifer" (http://www.verniana.org/volumes/02/HTML/SphericalGeometry.html, see Appendix), with one extension: The described approach has a 50% probability to compute the Antipode in contrast to the nearest circle center. From the mathematical view, also an Antipode of a result is a result, however, the expected circle is, of course, smallest circle that touches the three points. As a result, the distance from both (computed or its Antipode) is computed and the smaller distance is used.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - first position the triangle (latitude)
        lon1 - first position the triangle (longitude)
        lat2 - second position the triangle (latitude)
        lon2 - second position the triangle (longitude)
        lat3 - third position the triangle (latitude)
        lon3 - third position the triangle (longitude)
        Returns:
        array of three: [0]: center latitude, [1]: center longitude, [2] radius in meters.

      • greatCircleIntersection

        public static double[][] greatCircleIntersection(double lat1,
                                                 double lon1,
                                                 double lat2,
                                                 double lon2,
                                                 double lat3,
                                                 double lon3,
                                                 double lat4,
                                                 double lon4)
        Intersect two great circles, each given by two lat/long coordinates. As two great circles have two intersections, the method returns two positions.
        Parameters:
        lat1 - first position of the first great circle (latitude)
        lon1 - first position of the first great circle (longitude)
        lat2 - second position of the first great circle (latitude)
        lon2 - second position of the first great circle (longitude)
        lat3 - first position of the second great circle (latitude)
        lon3 - first position of the second great circle (longitude)
        lat4 - second position of the second great circle (latitude)
        lon4 - second position of the second great circle (longitude)
        Returns:
        two points where [0][0]: lat1, [0][1]: lon1 and [1][0]: lat2, [1][1]: lon2

      • nearestGreatCirclesIntersection

        public static double[] nearestGreatCirclesIntersection(double lat1,
                                                       double lon1,
                                                       double lat2,
                                                       double lon2,
                                                       double lat3,
                                                       double lon3,
                                                       double lat4,
                                                       double lon4)
        Intersect two great circles, each given by two lat/long coordinates. From the two intersections, return the intersection nearest to (lat1,lon1). This method is the more 'natural' than greatCircleIntersection(), as it ignores the antipode that may far away from the four given points. However, this method even returns an intersection, even though the intersection does not reside on the direct connection between (lat1,lon1) to (lat2,lon2) or (lat3,lon3) to (lat4,lon4). You may check that using residesOnDirectConnection().
        Parameters:
        lat1 - first position of the first great circle (latitude)
        lon1 - first position of the first great circle (longitude)
        lat2 - second position of the first great circle (latitude)
        lon2 - second position of the first great circle (longitude)
        lat3 - first position of the second great circle (latitude)
        lon3 - first position of the second great circle (longitude)
        lat4 - second position of the second great circle (latitude)
        lon4 - second position of the second great circle (longitude)
        Returns:
        position as array of 2

      • residesOnDirectConnection

        public static boolean residesOnDirectConnection(double latP,
                                                double lonP,
                                                double lat1,
                                                double lon1,
                                                double lat2,
                                                double lon2)
        Find out, if the point P resides on the direct connection between points 1 and 2. Returns false, if either, P does not even reside on the great circle of 1 and 2 or it resides on the great circle, but on the 'wrong side' (i.e. on the longer greater circle segment that connects 1 and 2).
        Parameters:
        latP - point to check (latitude)
        lonP - point to check (longitude)
        lat1 - first point latitude
        lon1 - first point longitude
        lat2 - second point latitude
        lon2 - second point longitude
        Returns:
        true, if P resides on the connection 1 to 2
